CreditLine: Gift of the estate of Mrs. Frances Eaton Weld, 1947
Description: Portraits of children of noble houses were often commissioned to be sent to distant relatives.  Even though the style of sleeves with a pattern of slits for easy movement and the painting style appear to be Italian, such a painting could have been made for relatives in northern Europe–for example, sent by the mother to her sister married into a distant noble family who might otherwise never "see" her nephew. This is one of three known versions, the other two probably earlier and possibly executed in Northern Europe, suggesting that the boy was from an important family. Sons were critical to maintaining the family line of inheritance and therefore status.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Déjà Vu? The Repeating Image in Renaissance and Baroque Art
Exhibitions.Textblock: Déjà Vu? The Repeating Image in Renaissance and Baroque Art. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore. 2007-2008.

MuseumLocation.DisplayCurrentLocation: Charles Street: Second Floor: Chamber of Wonders

Provenance: Mrs. Frances Eaton Weld; given to Walters Art Museum, 1947.
Title: Portrait of an Infant Boy Holding an Apple
